pros: This was my first design job as a student. I worked under another designer who left the company a year before I did, but she was wonderful. The other employees I worked with at INTO Mason were always so kind, helpful, and wanted the best for me. I'm really grateful I had this experience and that I was also able to learn a lot about design and the software! Because I was a student, they were always extremely flexible about my work schedule and stressed that my classes should always be prioritized over work. It felt like they really valued me, my time, and my potential.
cons: I worked here during the 2020 pandemic so of course, like most places of employment, things started getting a bit slow in terms of the work. Once my manager left, I had several other people managing me and other student workers, which often led to confusion on who I should report to or what I should do some days. They all did their best though and were genuinely trying to help me in any way they could. It was just another sad effect of COVID honestly.

pros:
Medical Benefits/Insurance are good
Leave Benefits are good
Retirement is good if hired for position that qualifies for 401k option
Education Benefit
cons:
The Leave amounts awarded to each employee classification are good, however employees hired for upper-level positions are often not in situations by which they can use their leave before it either expires; or rolls over.

Unfortunately, GMU does not pay out unused annual leave. Even though it is a benefit to work for a company that offers short-term disability to prevent employees from having to exhaust all of their sick leave for medical situations that require them to be out for an extended period of time. Employees continue to accrue annual leave while out on short-term disability; therefore, this can result in a catch 22 situation for employees who run into a 'use or lose' situation with their annual leave and the end of the year.
The Education Benefit is only applicable to taking paid courses at GMU; thus, this is a benefit if you are fortunate to have a major offered at GMU. 
Additional paid training in your area of work/specialty will depend on support by your individual supervisor and whether the Unit you work for have the funding support to cover it. Some Units are more encouraging than others when it comes this. It would be recommended to address this during the interview process.
Teleworking---outside of the pandemic, not all Units are agreeable to teleworking; so again, this is something to address during the interview process.

review_title: Flexible Company but Limited Growth Potential
job_title: Information Technology Specialist in Fairfax, VA
pros: Everything is very silo'd which has benefits and drawbacks. In my I.T. role, this felt more like working inside a small business but with big business policies. My three direct bosses were fairly flexible about taking time off when necessary, though your milage may vary depending on the college and department you work for. The benefits package is also top notch compared to private industry (the Cova care packages in particular were exceptionally helpful given my health).
cons: As everything is silo'd the possibility for job growth and promotion is virtually nonexistent unless you reapply for jobs outside of your immediate department. Getting information and answers across departments is also exceedingly difficult, so expect to be on your own with most problems you encounter. Annual raises don't occur either so expect your buying power to drop year over year until you leave.

review_title: Inconsistent work enviroment.  Don't expect raises.  Ever.
pros: It's a somewhat relaxed environment.  You get close to two weeks off at the end of the year.  If you can massage your work schedule, BIG IF... You can take classes for free. (6 credits a semester)
cons: If you have any ambition,they have enough happening there to make you believe you can make a difference. Just be prepared to have your work marginalized come review time.  If you move up from a low skill position to a substantially higher position internally, they basically have figured out how to justify underpaying you to the point of insult. They'll see you as qualified for the job, but NOT qualified to get the base salary.  On the other hand, if you come in from the outside, you can easily out earn your coworkers by as much as 25k.  But again, don't expect to ever get a raise.  GMU's IT department seems to have this defeated mentality, where they seem to indirectly promote minimum performance, since anything above that generally means that they have to fill out additional paperwork.  Training, classes and certs are encouraged, but not rewarded.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Fairfax, VA
pros: George Mason is a wonderfully diverse campus with students that work hard, are inspirational in their backgrounds and drive, and the staff is the icing on the cake.  In my department, I always felt welcome and supported, and being a GTA was absolutely priceless.  I hope to be a  professor someday and doing this for two years with support to get papers published while getting teaching experience was truly a gift.  TAships offer a full ride and come with a stipend, which was amazing and helped me finish my master's on an upswing.
cons: Schedules fluctuate between finals and midterms, so you have to be driven, as there is a lot of free time in your schedule to grade, do research, and do coursework.  I recommend GTAs get a set schedule and don't sleep in.  You are there to serve your students first and foremost.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Fairfax, VA
pros:
You get some experience tutoring and teaching.
The pedagogical training is thorough and the support while tutoring and teaching from both your cohort and your superiors is excellent.
Opportunities are available to teach and tutor in varying capacities in regards to both time and subject.
cons:
If you care about the quality of your teaching, your own studies may suffer due to time constraints.
Scheduling is always done late, and some people end up unhappy with their schedule.
The program is heavily weighted towards the MFA program in particular, so if you are an MA you may feel left out-- and will probably get compensated very differently --despite the fact that quite a few MFA students openly admit they have no interest in teaching or becoming better teachers.

review_title: Who says academia isn't a "good ol' boys" club, too?
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Fairfax, VA
pros:
I worked in the Volgenau School of Engineering, so the building was brand new (although I could tell that they ran out of budget for painting partway through). 

It's a college campus, so you can go out for a smoke or just walk through the forest and clear your mind. The network was BLAZING fast. Lastly, there was no need to worry about discrimination based on race, gender, sexual orientation, etc.
cons:
Unfortunately, I just did not get along with any of the professors for whom I was a GRA. One seemed like he only favored East Asians, and requests for assessments of my performance went ignored; I was simply let go at the last minute. The second professor was a robot with no personality or emotions. "You're not performing well because you've been diagnosed with MDD (major depressive disorder)? Well, that's your fault for not getting on the right medication sooner." Uh...okay boss.

In the summer, my office was as warm as Fargo, ND because I was the only one in there in a space with 6 cubes. Lack of body heat + lack of heat from desktop machines = brrr. I asked facilities multiple times to remedy this, only to have it return to sub-zero temperatures a couple days later.

review_title: The work atmosphere at GMu is good, the people are cordial and the atmosphere is pleasant.
pros: The university is growing exponentially and their is much opportunity to grow professionally with it.
cons: There is not a strong sense of community on campus (compared to other mid-size midwestern universities I have worked at) because it is so close to DC faculty/students are involved with many other outside commitments. It is not that people are unfriendly or unpleasant, but if you are accustom to having a strong sense of community with those you work and study with this campus environment is slightly different. Part of this may also be because the university is transitioning from a "commuter school" to a full-fledged "traditional" college campus. In addition, because they are transitioning from a "commuter" to "traditional" campus some of the internal organizational structures are lacking. For example, there is no central graduate college to handle all graduate student needs across departments. This burdens the departments of study to devise their own messy processes and procedures to handle graduate issues   - "traditional" universities have a central organizing body that streamlines this process.

review_title: Not good if you're a science graduate student
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Fairfax, VA
pros: The academics at the university are wonderful. Research is in interesting and relevant areas of science. Advisors can either be great help, or not much at all. Work-life balance is as good or bad as you choose to make it.
cons: Pay is awful. Do not expect to work as graduate teaching assistant or graduate research assistant and expect to live comfortable unless living with 3+ people. Administration is horrendous and does not care about graduate student concerns. Collaboration between researchers is mostly non existent, which I believe is missed opportunity. Amount of work required is insane for the pay if you are a teaching assistant. If you are a research assistant, work tends to be more tame. Expect to feel underappreciated.

pros:
George Mason has some bright individuals where you can learn how to resolve a lot of challenging professional problems. 

benefits of education is great because you can continually learn and grow
cons: upper management and too many politics and 'budget issues' to move up or grow.

review_title: George Mason great to work within your team, but not outside of it.
pros: Great state of Virginia  benefits package. Once you complete your first year you pretty much can't be fired. Working in the performing arts this was a great gig as it was full time with benefits. These jobs are few and far between in this industry. It was good to work within my department.
cons: As you can't be fired we have seen several people who couldn't perform were just transferred to other jobs in the school and the people with half their pay who were covering were made to continue with little compensation. Trying to get a hold of a competent HR rep was impossible some days.  Their was a definite chasm between management and the workers. To them everything was fine. After working three 18 hour days straight I was told that I should be thankful to have my job.

pros: you get to know the professors better and they can more easily write you a letter of recommendation. You also get to see a little bit of their life as a professor and start to realize why some of your classes are less than good. Sometimes the professor you are under doesn't really make you do much except write down a few notes but others expect you to walk around and help students with daily questions. you also get office hours where any student can come in asking for help but not many do so you can spend the time doing your homework and getting paid for it.
cons: The checks were almost always late. It didn't matter much for me cause I wasn't struggling for cash but if you are then expect to make several trips to the office asking for your check. Pay is very little and they only allow you to work 10 hours a week. Don't stay here for a long time.

pros:
-Students are dynamic and hardworking. They are easily the best part of my job.
-There is definitely a drive from leadership to be ahead of the curve in what we can offer in student affairs-- feels like we are always implementing new ideas and changes.
-The culture on campus encourages you to take your sick days and annual leave, and you are expected to leave work at work. Very rarely have I had to answer e-mails past 5pm.
-Within our division, there is a noticeable effort from leadership to increase collaboration between departments
-Plenty of opportunities for new professionals to engage with others on campus and to develop your skills away from your desk
-Free tuition is obviously a huge perk
cons:
-Will probably seem too erratic to someone who doesn't embrace change quickly
-Since it's a large school, there is a lot that happens at the VP level that we don't hear about
-Budget is and will always be an issue

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Fairfax, VA
pros: The university has many excellent faculty members, who tend to be accessible. Departments have a lot of flexibility on how they employ GRAs, making it less likely that you'll be stuck on projects you're not interested in. The proximity to DC government and gov-sector companies opens up opportunities for consulting, grants, and connections that aren't available many other places.
cons: The Fairfax campus is remote and hard-to-reach. The university provides few resources for graduate students to meet socially or professionally across departments; the large number of part-time students makes forming cohesive cohorts difficult as well. GRA pay is not competitive with many R1 schools that Mason wants to compete with. Despite this, students are required to pay many additional fees (e.g. parking) out-of-pocket.

review_title: A cold environment which does not support its PhD student neither financially nor academically.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Fairfax, VA
pros: A very convenient(small) campus with a lot of new buildings and too-old-to-care world class academics. You can do a lot but you will not achieve much.
cons:
I have been exposed to many instances of discrimination, racism and ignorance by more than few middle level administrator personnel. 
Financially I have been always unhappy as a graduate student researcher with 30+ hours teaching duty and no summer support. The school simply had no intention of supporting graduate students life or their academic ambitions. Not enough scholarship program. No university funded event for balancing grad life. Yet the poisonous academic competition was all over the place with less competent young faculties working to gain the attention of world-class retired ones. This place has really very little to compete with real research universities except its unconventional research directions.

pros: A really fun environment for students to make money and pay for books, school, etc.. Employers understand that you are a student first and foremost, and will help you schedule your work accordingly. Everyone still respects you and treats you as an adult, at least in my experience. Job opportunities can be easily searched for on HireMason through Blackboard. I know I totally sound like a plant from the University but I just loved all my jobs at Mason so I have nothing but good things to say.
cons: Parking is outrageously expensive, but if you already commute to/live on campus then it's not an extra expense. Also, working on campus may make people uncomfortable if they end up seeing or working for their friends while on the jo.

review_title: Top University to Work for in Student Affairs
pros: Great colleagues, open to innovation and creativity in your work, students are bright and fun to work with, opportunity for professional development, opportunity to be promoted, upper administration is willing to be mentors, new president is very transparent and connected to social media, overall best college/university I have ever worked for to date
cons: If you are not open to change and/or flexible this might not be the place for you, just appointed a new president Angel Cabrera so there could be changes in administration, strategic planning, direction of the university that may be challenging, there are multiple campuses so you may be asked to work on one or more depending on your role that could be a challenge, overall I did not find many cons but I am listing things that might be for those looking to work at Mason

review_title: Used to be a good place to work.....
pros: I am fortunate to have worked for a good boss most of my time here.
cons: I don't know anyone who is happy with their job now. Lots of turnover. No school spirit or company loyalty. Work/life balance is on the way out. I used to be proud to work here, but sadly think it's time to take my talent elsewhere. It's all about bringing in more money with the leadership. Upper management appears to be clueless. This is not a collaborative place to work anymore. Very sad....

job_title: Senior Web Designer in Fairfax, VA
pros: The medical insurance coverage is excellent and cheap. Flex time is available. It's a casual workplace in some departments. You can take a free class every semester.
cons:
If you are a professional who reports to faculty, you will be treated like you are the help; given lots of responsibility with minimal authority; and your professional goals will be of no relevance in polishing the faculty's CV. 

Pay scale way below similar private sector positions, and Virginia had a salary freeze on for FIVE YEARS.

job_title: Customer Service Manager in Fairfax, VA
pros: The ability to help, educate and assist student with there financial needs and helping to resolve there problems with student from 130 countries.  The interaction with faculty staff members and University professor's regarding there accounts, product and services.
cons: The ability to properly advance my 5 employees to a higher position or be considered for positions in other department due to Management.  Example, position become available and certain individual would then go behind close doors and the next thing we know they have the position without considering or interviewing other employees who were more qualified or may not be, the process was detrimental to the staff motivation.

review_title: Many of the best people you'll ever find, but the pay structure for starting students is weak.
job_title: Front Desk Mentor in Fairfax, VA
pros: The employees are kind and helpful. They make the time spent in the office enjoyable. This environment is the only reason I've stayed here for as long as I have.
cons: The pay structure is weak for a State school. Their financial management on the small and large scale is wasteful and frivolous. Parking is atrocious and you are forced to buy a Parking Permit from the school for approx. $300+ and the price continues to grow. There are no benefits for student positions (as expected) and the recognition of excellent service is minimal at best.

pros: Open to telecommuting and remote work. Encourages growth through access to free, albeit limited coursework per year. Youthful feel to being on campus. Access to free and regularly scheduled shuttle service from Fairfax Metro.
cons: If you drive to work, you'll have to pay to park. Little to no way to increase your salary based solely on your performance and/or performance reviews without the bureaucracy of others in your supervisory up-line being required to submit additional paperwork throughout the year... and that's only IF the Commonwealth is open to giving increases in that calendar year. Now, having said that, the Commonwealth does provide periodic state-wide increases to employees. These statewide increases are typically offset by changes to mandatory retirement contributions or increases to health/medical insurance premiums.

review_title: Used to be a great place to work
pros: I loved working at Mason until the new administration came on board.
cons: Great teachers, advisors and administrators have been forced out.  There is not enough infrastructure to support the growing number of students.  Mason had worked hard to raise the standards for admission.  Today the goal is to get as many students, especially out-of-state, as possible in the door to the detriment of the student experience and their education.  They are setting students up to fail by lowering the admission standards.  Work/life balance used to be a priority at Mason but that too has gone away.  There is no personal connection to employees anymore - the administration doesn't care about their people.  Morale is at an all-time low.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant, English in Fairfax, VA
pros: Full tuition waiver for graduate teaching assistants in the creative writing program; built-in community with fellow teaching assistants; build own syllabi and reading lists from the ground up; teach English composition, literature, and creative writing; required course in composition pedagogy before you're allowed to teach
cons: Unlivable stipend that must be supplemented with loans or other employment; extremely thin healthcare package; excessive number of students for English classes; pay accounts for twenty hours a week, but actual work is closer to forty; unsupportive supervisors in English composition department

pros: Free tuition up to a certain amount. Relatively laid back summers and winter breaks.
cons: Where to begin? Experience varies depending on the department you work for, my department is absolutely abysmal. Leadership has no vision and is only focused upwards without concern for the department. The leadership roles are filled by the incompetent and are in no way qualified for the roles they have. Those that actually do work constantly get thrown under the bus by supervisors. Few people are happy. Turnover is ridiculously high. And never in my few years of working have I ever been in a place where people have been fired, two people have been in the short time I've been here. Also university staff hasn't received a raise in over three years.

review_title: Great environment for learning mastering new skills quickly
pros: When I worked there, almost complete autonomy was expected of the student teachers. I was impressed that they expected students to learn new software quickly, in order to create lesson plans to teach it. They paid for certifications in all the software the students taught, so it was a quick way to seriously improve your resume. Respectful and fun environment.
cons: You have to deal with the usual slowness of working at a public university, such as learning the quirks of a finicky scanner, because there isn't budget to buy a new one.

review_title: GMU is a good institution surrounded by unscrupulous and mendacious departments.
pros: GMU is a great school situated in a really nice location.  The campus is expanding and adding new services that will ultimately benefit students.
cons: The department and division honors ineptness if you are in the inner circle.  If you are in the inner circle and fail at your job, the division will just find another position for you to take.  Anyone else would be out on the street.

pros:
Great management, really know your bosses
Flexible hours 
Great student-work life
Better pay than other jobs on campus
Variety of work
Excellent way to learn about how university works
Learn to cut through red tape as a student
cons:
High stress, short term events mixed with long boring weeks
Clients often rude, unappreciative
Office is at the mercy of the University
Advancement for part-time workers unclear

review_title: Comfortable but lacking opportunities for upward mobility
pros:
Management tends to leave you alone to focus on your job
Work/life balance is strong
Opportunities to telework and take advantage of flexible working schedules appreciated
Adequate budget and access to necessary tools
cons:
Mason wants to move forward without revisiting stagnant policies instituted when university was much smaller
No real upward mobility for non-tenure lines (curse of state employment)
Difficulty in retaining talent due to aforementioned reasons; lots of competition in area
Lots of dead weight

job_title: Research Associate Professor in Fairfax, VA
pros: Pleasant work environment. Growing institution with many new buildings. There are some world-class faculty members, and has aspirations of growing from regional university into a world-class research institution ...
cons: ... but sometimes does not seem to have the institutional knowledge and procedures needed to implement these goals effectively. Training is uneven; some people are extremely knowledgeable, others are less so.

review_title: A big school, but can be a great environment once you find your place in it.
job_title: Administrative and Office Specialist III in Fairfax, VA
pros:
I've worked at Mason in 3 different administrative positions for the last 15 years, so clearly I enjoy it here.  This is a big, bustling campus, which is invigorating if you like that kind of energy.  The population can be a mixed bag, but there are great people here, from dedicated faculty and staff to bright, engaged students.  It can feel overwhelming to be one tiny component of a giant organization, the trick is to focus on your immediate community and concentrate on the impact you can make there.

The benefits are good, and really the main reason I think people gravitate towards the university.  The luxury of having 2 weeks paid vacation during the holidays can not be overstated.  It can be hard to break into the field here, as I have experience hiring staff and each position can receive hundreds of applicants.  Once you're in, you can feel secure in your job and have an advantage applying for future positions within the university.  

Full-time employees can take 12 credits a year at no cost.  This is amazing if you're looking to finish/continue with your education, and the reason I initially sought employment here.

There are tons of resources here, everything from fitness centers, public transportation, professional development courses, workshops, conferences, theater performances...there are so many more opportunities outside of your 9-5pm job commitments.
cons:
This isn't a place where aggressively career minded people can expect to climb the ladder.  You come here for the security, not the potential for advancement.  People tend to get entrenched in their jobs, in my experience the number one source of turnover is retirement.  If you're looking to move up, the most efficient method seems to be by making small title increases moving from department to department.

Raises aren't really a thing.  We occasionally get cost of living increases, that's about it.

Traffic in this area is awful.  Some days I get here in 25 minutes, other days it takes me an hour or more.  It's hard to predict your commute time.

Northern Virginia is an expensive region to reside in.  Mason pays well for the area, but even so, unless you're a Dean or a Vice President or something I wouldn't take a job here with the expectation of buying a summer home.

With a school this large you can expect a lot of bureaucracy. Trying to get something done can often times require consulting with several other departments you had no idea even existed.

Parking is limited.

review_title: A perfect institution for students looking for experience or for professional looking for a good life-work balance.
pros: George Mason University stands behind their motto, "Where Innovation is Tradition". The rapid growth in recent years and increase in prestige presents opportunities for employees to grow and improve processes in a new and up-and-coming environment.
cons: Parking is highly competitive, and the quality of benefits tend to drive the overall salary average down. The constant construction can also be an inconvenience.

job_title: Senior Challenge Course Facilitator in Manassas, VA
pros: I get to work outdoors surrounded by fun-loving people (both colleagues and clients) at GMU's challenge course, a.k.a., "The EDGE." Staff training is built right into the on-boarding process and returning staff must maintain their skills and critical certifications (CPR, AED, 1st Aid ... and ACCT credentialing).
cons: As a part timer, there are no benefits beyond workman's compensation should you suffer from an accident. Pay comes in the form of hourly wages. Just about every part timer I know also needs a 2nd or 3rd job to live in NoVA.

review_title: Great higher education employer but could use better pay.
pros: Pros include things like time off, health benefits, work-life balance, coworkers, on campus food options, gym facilities, and a central location near public transportation.
cons: The salary is way too low considering cost of living in area. I understand it is a state job, but Fairfax County is in the top 5 most expensive areas of the United States. Also, the fact staff have to pay for the limited parking in addition to the low salaries is frustrating.

pros: Mason is a great place to work.  The university values staff and is intentional about recognizing hard work and effort.  People are genuinely nice and you get to work with great students in a diverse environment.  Week off between Christmas and New Years and some years, there's 2 full weeks off for the winter holidays
cons: Has trouble keeping up with the local private universities in terms of salary, tuition benefits can only be used for yourself, not for your spouse or your children, every place has its crazies

review_title: Freedom to Build and Teach as You Wish
pros: You have a lot of freedom in developing your course curriculum, how you teach it, what you cover, etc. Mason is driven by Adjuncts, particularly in the evening, and if you don’t mind not being part of the decision-making crowd, you can come in, teach your lessons, and go home with little trouble in just doing your job and enjoying teaching.
cons: Adjuncts are very removed from benefits, programs, etc., especially when you’re with the night crowd. Pay is okay, but could be better. Nighttime classroom support when you have technical issues with the equipment is spotty, too.

pros:
- Lots of opportunities for training through HR certificate programs and university trainings (customer service, advising students, working with undocumented students and dreamers, mental health first aid, etc.).
- Wellness university encourages work-life balance by offering lunchtime activities - soup cooking, yoga, brown bag lectures, Who's Walking Wednesdays, etc.
- Diverse student body and staff (many international students).
- University offers excellent benefits for full-time workers - healthcare, a variety of leave options and opportunities, a set number of free university classes per semester/year.
cons:
- Student involvement and school spirit is pretty low.
- University has grown quickly and doesn't know how to compensate to meet all student's needs.
- Major problem with the "Mason shuffle" - students, and even other faculty and staff, often get pushed from one department to another because few people seem to understand who is in charge of certain processes. Financial aid, student accounts, meal plans, registrar, and housing all try to direct students to other departments when they themselves are in charge of fixing the problems. As a staff member taking classes, I had to go to three different departments to get an answer to a simple class registration question.
- Students pay a lot of money to go to school and have a sense of entitlement - they demand that they should get things their way and threaten to go straight to President Cabrera if they don't get what they want.
- Hiring for faculty and staff vacancies takes FOREVER. Positions often go unfilled for long periods of time, making work more stressful for the individuals that have to complete more than one job for months at a time.

pros: Great colleagues, lovely campus, vibrant community of students, faculty and staff. I have a feeling this can vary significantly by department, but everyone I know (across a number of departments) is very happy at Mason. I work with some students and love their energy, enthusiasm, passion and commitment to excellence. Very impressed.
cons: You're part of a very large system, which can impact technology, etc, but honestly, I haven't had any issues even with the large system.

review_title: Term Faculty in the College of Health and Human Services
pros: Intelligent and Caring Faculty and Staff, in all corners of the building.  A lot of mentorship occurs with senior faculty supportive of those teaching with less experience.  Research focused with a a new Dean of our college.
cons: High demand for Research is difficult to balance with course work.

review_title: So close, but so far from being a good job
pros: I would say the job overall is easy. Stocking, taking cash register orders, assisting customers, and cleaning everything gets relatively easier over time. You get free food, from Burger King, Taco Bell, and Sub Connection, although the amount of food is obviously not enough to fill you up. The people I've worked with were very nice, and the environment was perfect for any college student hoping to make some quick cash. You can get a parking pass for ten dollars every week taken out of your paycheck, which would help pay for the EXPENSIVE AS IS parking that GMU issues on a daily basis.
cons: The management  hires many people who can't speak English, or do their job as well as most people who had their hours reduced could. The hours are hardly ever divided fairly. People who would call out would get it rejected, especially when it comes to exam week if the store is understaffed.The company policies are also kind of screwed up. The company Sodexo, pretty much controls an entire monopoly. So its no surprise that most of the students who go to GMU, are going to be ripped off inside campus. Its hard to move up in management, especially since they have a strict policy on punctuality, and yet people with no customer service experience get hired as Supervisors. Just because they needed the money to pay off their college 'debt.' Sodexo doesn't really care about your well being, and only care about making money and profiting off of you. But what company nowadays doesn't do that?

review_title: A solid way of gaining conflict resolution experience
pros:
They understand that your responsibilities as a student (academics, not extracurriculars) come first before the job.
Free housing (the main reason why most people take the job)
cons:
Opening and closing is always a mess, they always try a new method of running things each semester, it just leads to more chaos and confusion among the staff.
Different supervisors have different sets of expectations.

pros: The professional doors being an RA opens up are absolutely incredible, there are a lot of very respected individuals who were Resident Advisors at one point in their lives.
cons: Very different hours with a fair chunk of work happening after the normal school or working hours. High stress situations were common however a lot of training was given to each person who came through.

review_title: Good place to be if you want to work in higher ed and don't mind being way underpaid
pros: The work isn't difficult and the expectations are not high
cons:
definitely underpaid as a result of years of wage freezes due to the state budget issues
no accountability, some people are just warm bodies that fill positions
not a lot of opportunity for advancement, you have to be in the right place at the right time to move forward in your career

pros: -great benefits including:  free tuition (up to 12 credits/year if you're full-time), lots of paid time off, decent medical insurance
cons:
-pay for parking and it's not even remotely close to your building. expect at least a 7 min walk. 
-not enough flexibility in hours
-commute
-if there's an event at the Patriot Center, good luck getting around and finding parking

pros: The new renovations have finished in the Art Department and the building is quite nice.  Even though I do not have a Doctorate my hard work is rewarded and I remain happily employed.
cons: The decision making process for management is sometimes clandestine. Management decisions that would seem to require faculty support are sometimes made without any discussion.

review_title: Working at GMU has been a helpful, rewarding, and successful experience.
pros: GMU is very flexible when it comes to scheduling, working around the student's availability presented by class load.  Inside the IT department, all employees and management are friendly and helpful.
cons: The ResTech job itself within the IT department was fairly easy and paid decently for a quarter-time (10 hr) student, but the job wasn't very technically interesting or challenging.

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Fairfax, VA
pros: They allow undergraduates to work part-time as teaching assistants for CS classes which you have taken and done well in. It is a good opportunity to help students, which in turn helps you build on your CS skills. The position is also very flexible in terms of hours. They understand that most of the students working are full-time students so you can decide which days/times works best for you.
cons: Some GTAs do not require attendance during labs, so some times majority of class will not show up to lab

review_title: Classroom and Lab Support Assistant Technician
job_title: Classroom and Lab Support Assistant Technician in Fairfax, VA
pros: Very flexible work schedule, very low stress work environment. Kind and respectful full time techs/management.
cons: Some of the shifts can be little too late, and there is a high turnover so you don't really get to know some of the other assistant technicians.  The pay could be higher too.

pros: The working environment is what you make it out to be. If you have strong interpersonal skills you can turn a negative interaction with a customer (Student or Faculty) in to a positive one. My coworkers at GMU are awesome people, full of enthusiasm with well-rounded skills to assist one another in every shape and way.
cons: You may experience some rude people as an office assistant but that's part of the job. Being able to handle both stressful and non-stressful situations to the best of your ability, while providing accurate responses.

pros: The professors are hard working and pay attention to the students' needs. The students work closely with the the professors and the latter in general pay individual student attention.
cons: It it growing very rapidly so it could be a challenge for both professors and students...the class sizes could be large so it might get harder for the prof to give individual student attention

review_title: Not a real difficult place to work but really hard to advance or get compensated for your hard work.
job_title: Trades Tech III in Fairfax Station, VA
pros: Friendly work place , good co-workers and very little pressure from supervisors . Lots of leave and great benefits. Plenty of great place to eat and get coffee.
cons: The Pay is very low for Northern VA .When you do get a raise it really doesn't amount to much. Very low opportunity to advance to high positions.

pros: The position was overall good and they were generally considerate of the school/work balance. The other RAs are great and I made some of my best friends while working there. Furthermore RAing was wonderful for the resume because it was strong leadership experience.
cons: If you have a bad RD they can ruin your experience. There isn't really much you can do about this, so cross your fingers.

review_title: Great place to work while you're a student
pros: The Collaborative Learning Hub is a great opportunity to build a lot of different skills while you're going through school.  You'll become proficient ins software that is typically used throughout the working world. You'll build a lot of skills and learn a lot about working with a variety of different people.
cons: The pay isn't extremely high for the area. Occasionally office politics show up, but rarely change the day-to-day operation of the lab.

pros: Great place to work. Great faculty and students. The university is growing in research and academic standing. This is an excellent place to work as a faculty member and a pleasant environment. They go out of their way to make adjuncts feel welcomed.
cons: None other than being an adjunct carries no benefits. However that is the nature of adjunct work. Also as an adjunct you get moved around from class to class. But again not unique to GMU but to adjunct lie.

review_title: A bureaucratic higher education environment where pay is lower than average and the environment varies from unit to unit
pros: The atmosphere can be relaxed. You are trading salary for flexibility, in some cases.
cons: The environment can be retrograde, with lip service given to things like remote work friendliness. Salaries are low. There are a lot of egos and, oddly, a lot of paranoia.

review_title: George Mason is a great public school for lecturers, instructors, and professors.
pros: The working atmosphere is great. Colleagues are supportive with your work. Most students are respectful to the teachers. The administrative side of George Mason is smooth as well.
cons: I don't think is there anything on the downside of working at George Mason University. The compensation could be a little better.

job_title: Fiscal and Administrative Specialist in Fairfax, VA
pros: Good benefits, nice campus, nice people
cons: Not all offices allow flexible schedules like Mason promotes. The dean of each college can make or break the work culture within that college. There is defiantly a hierarchy of importance and the faculty are respected above the staff. There is no pathway to grow or move up without changing positions.

pros: In addition to working on a college campus, free classes are perk to many employees. The DC area is very exciting.
cons: Situated in one of the most expensive areas in the country, salaries do not compare. Academia in general suffers from a mix of poor managers. Individual departments vary greatly.

review_title: I enjoyed my experience as a TA
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Fairfax, VA
pros: The pay is good. The professor for the course for which I am a TA was really helpful and cooperative. The instructions given were quite clear
cons: In some of the courses, there may be more than one TA. Further, for a course there may be two professors taking a particular course. For such courses, there's always a degree of confusion while grading as the criterion specified in the rubic may not be applicable to a particular batch of students

review_title: Family Oriented Workplace ONLY in Fairfax
pros: Family friendly, team oriented, great people as supervisors.  Really believe in professional development.  Some of the best benefits available - exceptional leave policy and really try to accommodate working parents.
cons: Fairfax campus is the place to be - PW campus is a nightmare.  Management is really lacking even with new hires.   Loved working in Fairfax and absolutely hated working in Prince William.  Would never have left Mason but my position was moved to PW.

review_title: My experience at GMU has been satisfying despite the growing pains of being at a young and upcoming university.
pros: Great place to be a young professional where opportunities are awarded to you that are not offered at other research institutions across the country.
cons: Due to "innovation being tradition" and the young age of the school, there is no such thing as consistency or true tradition. Things are ever changing and processes are not set in stone; often leading to confusion on the job and inefficient work.

pros: Close knit department.  Generally supportive environment.  Lots of opportunities for collaboration in the DC area.  Some very talented and dedicated faculty.
cons: Can be difficult to report problems depending on who is in charge at a given time.  Lots of administration changes, and funding situations change with management.

pros: Very flexible place to work; good work life balance. Main campus is very nice  and in a good area. Traffic can be bad. Lots of time off
cons: Very political in many offices. Favors people who have been there a long time regardless of how good they are at their job. No raises unless you are lucky and argue them.

job_title: Client Services Representative in Fairfax, VA
pros: The trainings prepare you to become a supervisor in any job you pursue.The coworkers all get along and create a comfortable working environment.Their are opportunities to expand your skills through workshops and training sessions.
cons: Can be stressful dealing with difficult people but you must power through it.Every interaction with a client just prepares you to handle clients of all types an help you think quickly on your feet.

review_title: It was a real time experience working part time and fun to work with good senior managers
pros: Good Infrastructure, Locality-Fairfax being the best county to live in, environment, opportunities, diversified culture with many different events throughout the year.
cons: Infrastructure can be developed even further,need more food outlets, increase bus schedules at the night time and create more affiliations with companies

review_title: University great work-life policies, but beware working for faculty
pros: Strong support for telecommuting. Great medical benefits. Relaxed dress code. Defined benefit plan for current employees.
cons: Faculty simply do not know how to supervise or manage highly skilled professionals. They are treated as nothing more than support staff. There is no 360-degree review so there is no way that faculty are held accountable for poor management skills.

review_title: Great, inviting place to work for
pros: Great employee benefits and time off! Really friendly community and a good place to get a lot of exposure to different elements of the academic community. Felt like there was a nice balance of work/personal life.
cons: Would need to work with your manager about paths for professional development and promotions - that varies based upon department.

review_title: Research Professor: Soft Money Position, like industry but with resources of a university
job_title: Research Assistant Professor in Fairfax, VA
pros: There are a lot of smart people around, and if you have time there are fantastic opportunities.  The benefits are excellent.  It is an exciting place, still growing and trying new things.
cons: Research professors (soft money hires) often cannot take their vacation hours because they are either writing proposals to cover their job, or on contract with deadlines, deliverables, and less support for these than at a for-profit company.

pros: Like all the skills I gained that helped me to get a better job. I was hoping to do more that would allow me to advance in the department but they did not think the same thing.
cons: Was meant to get tuition stipend while I worked on my Masters degree. But they decided to revoke the stipend and cut my hours. Was financially the worst thing to happen given I needed the money to pay for the school.

review_title: Great place to work but has areas to improve
pros:
Ive been working at Mason for nearly a year and have enjoyed my experience overall. The positives of working here are:
Nice people to work with
Students are usually appreciative of your help
Nice campus
Strong sense of diversity
cons:
Pay is not as high as other universities
Space is limited and tight
Faculty engagement is low

review_title: I love working at George Mason University. I have been Adjunct professor for thirteen years. It's a wonderful place.
job_title: Full-time French Adjunct Professor in Fairfax, VA
pros: It's friendly and welcoming. I have learned so much being being a teacher from my colleagues and my coordinators. My teaching skills has improved very much in the last 6 years.
cons: I don't have benefits in my current job as a part-time adjunct professor. I would like to have benefits in the next job. I am not paid during the Summer.

review_title: Frustrated with the low pay and lack of reward for hard work
pros: Flexible schedule, good immediate supervisor, educational benefits
cons: Little recognition for hard work, Raises are rare, and basically the same for everyone, whether you work hard or just cruise. Virginia's current fiscal deficit probably means a few more years without raises. Extremely difficult to get rid of employees that are not performing.

review_title: Good experience, great place for grad school
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Fairfax, VA
pros: The department provided great support, and it was a good learning experience. The stipend for a TA was decent, with increases if you've taught before.
cons: There was no tuition assistance available as a master's student, even though PhD students received it automatically without having more experience.

job_title: 3D-Gestalter / Künstlerischer Leiter / Mitarbeiter Kreativstrategien in Manassas, VA
pros: The benefit package was competitive but that is changing  . Good  401k package with Flex schedule options . Standard health insurance benefit option .
cons: Moving up is a struggle . Absolute struggle with low raises option . The Human Resources department is not what it used to be . The older more understanding human resource have left the company .

review_title: Growing pains to become a research university
pros: A wonderful and exciting place place to work as a researcher.  A lot of freedom to make an impact in any area, but not much support from admin. It is what you should expect in a young research university.
cons: The research professorships are not well established and it is about the same as working for a private company.  GMU has a very tiered system with tenure track faculty at the top.

pros:
The people are great to work for.
Get to help people with computer issues
Help students pick out the right computer for their major
cons:
As a student they won't pay you anything even though NOVA is an expensive area to live in.
Their are no benefits as a student.

pros: great community, fun work, all your ideas will be heard. managers will do the best they can to prepare you for the real world--they will really do anything they can to help out.
cons: lack of organization. a lot of times you don't know what you're supposed to do for a project until youre trying to do it.

job_title: Processing Assistant In International Programs in Fairfax, VA
pros: The people are often incredibly kind and nice! Most of the teaching staff and administration staff really seem bent on helping student matriculate well.
cons: A lot of what happens on the job is political. Staff isn't always treated as essential and sometimes there's a lack of communication regarding immediate changes in the workplace.

pros: The stated mission is great.  The benefits are wonderful, but the salary is not as high as other opportunities in the area.  This is offset by the fact that you get to do work for the community and really have an impact.
cons: Depending on where you work, the department may have terrible culture, especially for women.  There are other people who are working hard to improve these pockets - but if you don't find those people, you could feel very isolated.  Hopefully you will find one of the great departments!

pros: Working at GMU has amazing benefits. I've been able to network with people across all kinds of disciplines, HR here is amazing to work with and always helpful as well.
cons: The only con is that sometime the salary at the university will be a little bit lower than jobs elsewhere. This is balanced pretty fairly with the other benefits that they offer though, such as tuition wavers, etc.

pros:
Free tuition- 6 credits free for two semesters a year - earn a bachelor's, master's and/or PhD.  
Good location - Fairfax, VA
Great place to get your foot in the door - get sent to the academy - get certifications under your belt
cons: Bad pay. Paying for parking is expensive and mandatory.  Rotating shifts.  Management.  Lack of promotions.  No one on campus likes the police - faculty, staff or students.

review_title: It was good, decent work environment but work ethic could have been better
job_title: Cashier (At Restaurant ) and GTA in Fairfax, VA
pros: I worked both as a GTA (Gradiate Teaching Assistant) as well as a cashier at the local restaurant on campus. Both places I found great colleagues and helpful people. I know that this is going to sound strange but I actually preferred my work as a cashier.
cons: Work Distribution needs reconsideration as a lot of people are doing the work intended for others

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Fairfax, VA
pros:
Great hours
Friendly professors
Good location as it is hidden in the suburbs. 
Food options available, with plenty of coffee
cons:
Parking is just the worst, no way to get around that
Traffic is always a nightmare
You have to deal with college kids, but it is a university so you should know that already

job_title: Academic Programs Marketing Manager in Fairfax, VA
pros: CVPA is great, the people are great, the environment is inclusive. I love it here.
cons: I get paid way below the median rate for my job duties, there is no clear direction on how to move up. No mentorship programs for staff. No dependant tuition benefits like most public universities.

pros: Flexibility and opportunity. GMU gives employees a lot of leeway to expand, grow and develop their position. Because it's a newer university, it isn't guided by old traditions that create needless restrictions as some older universities.
cons: GMU is a mid-level public university. It does not yet have the prestige of a top-tier or even public flag-ship university, which can make it difficult to build connections outside the college and acquire funding for projects.

job_title: Education Support Specialist II in Fairfax, VA
pros: I loved the benefits at GMU. As a full time employee, I got 12 credits of tuition waived each academic year. It makes up for the low salaries. Also there is a lot of room for advancement and network in the community.

pros: Folks here are very understanding about flexibility. I have children, so that's a necessity. Also, I genuinely like and feel inspired by some of my co-workers. Like any university, it's a mecca for smart, thoughtful people. Some facilities are new and beautiful.
cons: Salaries for staff are abysmal. But, I could swallow that if the institutional culture was healthy, and it's just not. Everywhere you turn, you run into people who won't communicate, which makes it extraordinarily difficult to do your job well. I think there is just a lot of fear here. People don't get positive feedback and make so little money that they hold on to the only thing they have - control of information. I feel like I spend every day hitting my head against a wall. Also, Mason has a very poor relationship with the Commonwealth of Virginia - but since it's a state school, the Commonwealth makes the rules. So the work here is a constant effort to walk the line between what Mason wants and what the Commonwealth requires. It's not very rewarding. This is all from the staff viewpoint. I'm sure faculty has a different experience. There seems to be developmental support for people who want to grow from senior leadership roles to even-more-senior leadership roles, but nothing at all for people who want to grow from mid-level roles.
